lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, arrays enable dynamic list rendering and easy data sharing between components, making UIs more interactive and responsive.

Let's learn how to use them in React.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to passing simple values, we can pass an array as a prop to a component.

Put the array inside an embedded expression to pass it as the value for the property students.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Logging the array to the console can help us understand its structure and debug any issues.

Let's log the array of students.

Make sure to pick console.log, followed by students.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
React allows us to display arrays directly in our JSX by mapping over them to create elements for each item.

Start by creating an unordered list element to serve as a wrapper for the list items.

Make sure to pick <ul>, followed by </ul>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the ES6 array method map to iterate over all elements inside an embedded expression.

Make sure to pick students, followed by .map.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We define the element inside the parameter of the map function.

Define student as the parameter to allow us to later access the individual element by the variable student.

Make sure to pick ( followed by student and then ), => {}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We want to return a li element for every element of the students that can be rendered by React.

Make sure to pick <li>, followed by </li>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside the li element, we can use another embedded expression to render the array's element.

Make sure to pick {, followed by student, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render an array of wizard names using React.

Make sure to pick wizards followed by .map and then wizard, wizard.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is the correct way to map over an array to render each item in React?

{movies.map(movie => <li>{movie}</li>)}{movies.forEach(movie => <li>{movie}</li>)}{movies.each(movie => <li>{movie}</li>)}{movies.loop(movie => <li>{movie}</li>)}

{movies.map(movie => <li>{movie}</li>)}.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of Pokmon.

Make sure to pick <ul> followed by <li> and then {, pokemon, }, </li>, </ul>.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will this code render on the screen?

A list of Apple, Banana, CherryA single string AppleBananaCherryNothing will be renderedAn error will occur

A list of Apple, Banana, Cherry.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of movie characters using map.

Make sure to type .map.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
When rendering a list of items from an array in React, which function will you use?

mapjoinfilterreduce

Make sure to pick map.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of car brands using React.

Make sure to pick <ul> followed by brands and then .map, brand, <li>{brand}</li>, </ul>.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's continue looking at how we can handle arrays in React.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ordered lists in JSX work as HTML-ordered lists.

Create an ol element that holds multiple li elements.

Make sure to pick <ol> followed by <li> and then </li>, </ol>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
React expects a unique key for every list, whether unordered or ordered. To satisfy this expectation, we must use the key property.

Assign the element directly as key for the li element.

Make sure to pick key followed by = and then {, animal, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The key property helps React keep track of which items in a list change and makes updating and rendering lists more efficient.

Make sure to type key.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the map function, we can define a second argument to access the index of each item.

Define index as the second argument of the map function.

Make sure to pick ,, followed by index.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
As a next step, we can use the index as the unique key. This can be helpful when the items are potentially not unique.

Use index for the key to ensure the key is unique.

Make sure to pick index, followed by index.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the purpose of using a key in a list?

To help React identify which items have changedTo sort the list alphabeticallyTo add styles to the list itemsTo convert the list into a JSON object

To help React identify which items have changed.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code an ordered list of fruits using React.

Make sure to pick <ol> followed by <li key={index}> and then </li>, </ol>.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you assign a unique key to each list item in React?

By using a unique identifier or indexBy setting it in CSSBy using the same key for every itemBy assigning the key in a separate JSON file

By using a unique identifier or index.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using map, first, access the element of the array and then the index of that element.

Make sure to pick genre, followed by ,, and finally index.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the outcome of the following code block?

A list of colors with each color displayed as a list itemAn error due to missing CSSNo output as the code is incompleteAn ordered list instead of an unordered list

A list of colors with each color displayed as a list item.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the index of the array's element to set the key.

Make sure to pick index, followed by key, and finally index.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's continue looking at how we can handle arrays in React.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with arrays, we don't have to use exclusively lists. Let's explore how to use a different layout.

Create a p element as the wrapper for the array's elements.

Make sure to pick <p>, followed by </p>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside the p element, we can render other elements like span elements to display the array's elements.

Create a span element and render the item. Notice the whitespace after the embedded expression to leave room between the words.

Make sure to pick <span key={index}>, followed by {item}, and finally </span>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can add text to the p wrapper before and after the rendered array.

We use embedded expressions that render a string with whitespace to add whitespace to the rendered output.

Make sure to pick {" "}, followed by {" "}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Embedded expressions are a powerful tool for customizing the rendered output.

Use an inline if-else statement to render a comma for all elements except the last one.

Make sure to pick index < items.length - 1, followed by ?, and finally :.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can go even further and render an and for the last item of a list.

The possibilities with embedded expression are endless.

Make sure to pick index === items.length - 2, followed by ", and ", and finally "".

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list of animals using a React component and display them inside a span element.

Make sure to pick span, followed by key={index}, and finally span.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component to render a sentence describing a list of movies using embedded expressions.

Make sure to pick titles followed by .map and then (, title,, index, ).

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using the map method to render lists in React, why should we provide a key prop to each item?

To help React identify which items have changedTo make the list display horizontallyTo ensure each item is uniqueTo apply styles to items

To help React identify which items have changed.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use inline expressions to conditionally render a message based on the number of characters in a superhero name array.

Make sure to pick name.length > 6, followed by ?, and finally :.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Using arrays as state variables, we can track a collection of dynamic data within a component.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using an array as the value of a state variable, we can save multiple values within that one state variable.

Make sure to pick tools followed by setTools and then [, ].

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with state, we can't just append elements to the array. We need to set a new array as the value of the state variable.

Set the state variable tools to a new empty array when the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick setTools, followed by [].

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To create a new array that holds the values of another array, we can use the spread operator.

Use the spread operator inside a new array to pass a new array with all the values from the old state variable to the setter function.

Make sure to pick setTools, followed by ..., and finally tools.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we define more items inside the new array, they will also be added to it.

Add another item with the value "item" to the array. Give it a shot by clicking the button to see the array grow.

Make sure to pick [ followed by , and then "Item", ].

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The spread operator is a handy tool to add a new item to an array since we can't use append to modify the current state variable directly.

We must do it this way so React recognizes the state change and re-renders the component accordingly.

Make sure to pick [ followed by ... and then tools, ,, "Item", ].

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a state variable favorites and display its content.

Make sure to pick favorites, followed by useState, and finally favorites.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following code snippets correctly uses the spread operator to add an item to the movies array state in a React component?

setMovies([...movies, "Inception"]);movies.push("Inception");setMovies("Inception", ...movies);setMovies([movies.concat("Inception")]);

setMovies([...movies, "Inception"]);.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add "Captain America" to the avengers state variable using the spread operator.

Make sure to pick ..., followed by avengers, and finally "Captain America".

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the main advantage of using the spread operator when updating array state in React?

It creates a new array, allowing React to detect changes and re-render the componentIt directly modifies the original array, saving memoryIt allows you to append elements to the original state variable directlyIt is a faster way to add elements compared to other methods

It creates a new array, allowing React to detect changes and re-render the component.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Ensure to add "George" to the array bandMembers using the spread operator.

Make sure to type ...bandMembers.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which method below correctly updates a React state array with an additional string?

setMovies([...movies, "Inception"]);movies = movies.concat("Inception");movies[movies.length] = "Inception";pushMovie("Inception");

setMovies([...movies, "Inception"]);.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a stateful component to manage a task list. And add a new task "Read a book" to it.

Make sure to pick [tasks, setTasks] followed by useState and then setTasks, ...tasks, "Read a book".

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is it important to use the spread operator or similar methods to update state values in React?

To ensure React can detect changes to the state and properly re-render the componentBecause it makes the code look cleanerTo prevent syntax errors in JavaScriptTo improve application performance by modifying arrays directly

To ensure React can detect changes to the state and properly re-render the component.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Develop a state management system for favorite movies in a component. Add "The Godfather" to this list.

Make sure to pick [movies, setMovies] followed by useState and then setMovies, [, ...movies, ,, "The Godfather", ].

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if you try to directly modify the state array using array.push() in a React component?

The state won't change and React won't re-render the componentThe app will crash with an errorIt will modify the array and re-render automaticallyThe state array will reset to its initial value

The state won't change and React won't re-render the component.
